Let ... and let ... be the largest possible size of ... such that every ... has ... solutions to ... with ....

overview.problemStatement:
Forum
Favourites

More

Random Solved

Let $k\geq 2$ and let $g_k(n)$ be the largest possible size of $A\subseteq \{1,\ldots,n\}$ such that every $m$ has $<k$ solutions to $m=a_1a_2$ with $a_1<a_2\in A$.

Is it true that\[g_3(n)=\frac{\log\log n}{\log n}n+(c+o(1))\frac{n}{(\log n)^2}\]for some constant $c$?



Erd\H{o}s \cite{Er64d} proved that if $2^{r-1}<k\leq 2^r$ then\[g_k(n) \sim \frac{(\log\log n)^{r-1}}{(r-1)!\log n}n\](which is the asymptotic count of those integers $\leq n$ with $r$ distinct prime factors).

In particular the asymptotics of $g_k(n)$ are known; in \cite{Er69b} Erd\H{o}s discussed the second order terms, and this question is implicit (especially when compared to the explicit question [425] he asked on several occasions). For $k=3$ he could prove the existence of some $0<c_1\leq c_2$ such that\[\frac{\log\log n}{\log n}n+c_1\frac{n}{(\log n)^2}\leq g_3(n)\leq \frac{\log\log n}{\log n}n+c_2\frac{n}{(\log n)^2}.\]The special case $k=2$ is the subject of [425].




References


[Er64d] P. Erd\H{o}s, On the multiplicative representation of integers. Israel Journal of Mathematics (1964).

[Er69b] Erd\H{o}s, P., Problems and results in chromatic graph theory. Proof Techniques in Graph Theory (Proc. Second Ann
Arbor Graph Theory Conf., Ann Arbor, Mich.,
1968) (1969), 27-35.
